org.apache.juneau

Class BeanContext

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.juneau.Context
      • org.apache.juneau.BeanContext

  • public class BeanContext
extends Context
    Core class of the Juneau architecture.

    This class servers multiple purposes:

    • Provides the ability to wrap beans inside Map interfaces.
    • Serves as a repository for metadata on POJOs, such as associated transforms, property namers, etc... which are used to tailor how POJOs are serialized and parsed.
    • Serves as a common utility class for all Serializers and Parsers for serializing and parsing Java beans.
    Bean Contexts

    Typically, it will be sufficient to use the existing DEFAULT contexts for creating bean maps. However, if you want to tweak any of the settings on the context, you must either clone the default context or create a new one from scratch (whichever is simpler for you). You'll notice that this context class uses a fluent interface for defining settings.

    Bean contexts are created by context factories. The settings on a bean context are fixed at the point they are created by the factory.

    BeanContext settings
    BeanContexts have several settings that can be used to tweak behavior on how beans are handled. These are denoted as the static BEAN_* fields on this class.

    Some settings (e.g. BEAN_beansRequireDefaultConstructor) are used to differentiate between bean and non-bean classes. Attempting to create a bean map around one of these objects will throw a BeanRuntimeException. The purpose for this behavior is so that the serializers can identify these non-bean classes and convert them to plain strings using the Object.toString() method.

    Some settings (e.g. BEAN_beanFieldVisibility) are used to determine what kinds of properties are detected on beans.

    Some settings (e.g. BEAN_beanMapPutReturnsOldValue) change the runtime behavior of bean maps.

    Settings are specified using the ContextFactory.setProperty(String, Object) method and related convenience methods.

    Examples

    // Construct a context from scratch. BeanContext beanContext = ContextFactory.create() .setProperty(BeanContext.BEAN_beansRequireDefaultConstructor, true) .addNotBeanClasses(Foo.class) .getBeanContext(); // Clone an existing context factory. BeanContext beanContext = ContextFactory.create(otherConfig) .setProperty(BeanContext.BEAN_beansRequireDefaultConstructor, true) .addNotBeanClasses(Foo.class) .getBeanContext();

    Bean Maps

    BeanMaps are wrappers around Java beans that allow properties to be retrieved and set using the common Map.put(Object,Object) and Map.get(Object) methods.

    Bean maps are created in two ways...

    1. BeanContext.forBean() - Wraps an existing bean inside a Map wrapper.
    2. BeanContext.newInstance() - Create a new bean instance wrapped in a Map wrapper.
    Examples

    // A sample bean class public class Person { public String getName(); public void setName(String name); public int getAge(); public void setAge(int age); } // Wrap an existing bean in a new bean map BeanMap<Person> m1 = BeanContext.DEFAULT.forBean(new Person()); m1.put("name", "John Smith"); m1.put("age", 45); // Create a new bean instance wrapped in a new bean map BeanMap<Person> m2 = BeanContext.DEFAULT.newInstance(Person.class); m2.put("name", "John Smith"); m2.put("age", 45); Person p = m2.getBean(); // Get the bean instance that was created.

    Bean Annotations

    This package contains annotations that can be applied to class definitions to override what properties are detected on a bean.

    Examples

    // Bean class definition where only property 'name' is detected. @Bean(properties={"name"}) public class Person { public String getName(); public void setName(String name); public int getAge(); public void setAge(int age); }

    See @Bean and @BeanProperty for more information.

    Beans with read-only properties

    Bean maps can also be defined on top of beans with read-only properties by adding a @BeanConstructor annotation to one of the constructors on the bean class. This will allow read-only properties to be set through constructor arguments.

    When the @BeanConstructor annotation is present, bean instantiation is delayed until the call to BeanMap.getBean(). Until then, bean property values are stored in a local cache until getBean() is called. Because of this additional caching step, parsing into read-only beans tends to be slower and use more memory than parsing into beans with writable properties.

    Attempting to call BeanMap.put(String,Object) on a read-only property after calling BeanMap.getBean() will result in a BeanRuntimeException being thrown. Multiple calls to BeanMap.getBean() will return the same bean instance.

    Beans can be defined with a combination of read-only and read-write properties.

    See @BeanConstructor for more information.

    Transforms

    Transforms are used to tailor how beans and non-beans are handled.
    There are two subclasses of transforms:

    1. BeanTransform - Allows you to tailor handling of bean classes. This class can be considered a programmatic equivalent to the Bean annotation when annotating classes are not possible (e.g. you don't have access to the source).
    2. PojoTransform - Allows you to convert objects to serializable forms.

    See org.apache.juneau.transform for more information.

    ClassMetas

    The ClassMeta class is a wrapper around Class object that provides cached information about that class (e.g. whether it's a Map or Collection or bean).

    As a general rule, it's best to reuse bean contexts (and therefore serializers and parsers too) whenever possible since it takes some time to populate the internal ClassMeta object cache. By reusing bean contexts, the class type metadata only needs to be calculated once which significantly improves performance.

    See ClassMeta for more information.

    Author:
    Barry M. Caceres, James Bognar (james.bognar@salesforce.com)

    • Field Detail

      • BEAN_beansRequireDefaultConstructor

        public static final String BEAN_beansRequireDefaultConstructor
        Require no-arg constructor (Boolean, default=false).

        If true, a Java class must implement a default no-arg constructor to be considered a bean.

        The @Bean annotation can be used on a class to override this setting when true.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_beansRequireSerializable

        public static final String BEAN_beansRequireSerializable
        Require Serializable interface (Boolean, default=false).

        If true, a Java class must implement the Serializable interface to be considered a bean.

        The @Bean annotation can be used on a class to override this setting when true.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_beansRequireSettersForGetters

        public static final String BEAN_beansRequireSettersForGetters
        Require setters for getters (Boolean, default=false).

        If true, only getters that have equivalent setters will be considered as properties on a bean. Otherwise, they will be ignored.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_beansRequireSomeProperties

        public static final String BEAN_beansRequireSomeProperties
        Require some properties (Boolean, default=true).

        If true, then a Java class must contain at least 1 property to be considered a bean.

        The @Bean annotation can be used on a class to override this setting when true.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_beanMapPutReturnsOldValue

        public static final String BEAN_beanMapPutReturnsOldValue
        Put returns old value (Boolean, default=false).

        If true, then the BeanMap.put() method will return old property values.

        Disabled by default because it introduces a slight performance penalty.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_beanConstructorVisibility

        public static final String BEAN_beanConstructorVisibility
        Look for bean constructors with the specified minimum visibility (Visibility, default=Visibility.PUBLIC).
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_beanClassVisibility

        public static final String BEAN_beanClassVisibility
        Look for bean classes with the specified minimum visibility (Visibility, default=Visibility.PUBLIC).

        Classes are not considered beans unless they meet the minimum visibility requirements. For example, if the visibility is PUBLIC and the bean class is protected, then the class will not be interpreted as a bean class.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_beanFieldVisibility

        public static final String BEAN_beanFieldVisibility
        Look for bean fields with the specified minimum visibility (Visibility, default=Visibility.PUBLIC).

        Fields are not considered bean properties unless they meet the minimum visibility requirements. For example, if the visibility is PUBLIC and the bean field is protected, then the field will not be interpreted as a bean property.

        Use Visibility.NONE to prevent bean fields from being interpreted as bean properties altogether.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_methodVisibility

        public static final String BEAN_methodVisibility
        Look for bean methods with the specified minimum visibility (Visibility, default=Visibility.PUBLIC).

        Methods are not considered bean getters/setters unless they meet the minimum visibility requirements. For example, if the visibility is PUBLIC and the bean method is protected, then the method will not be interpreted as a bean getter or setter.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_useJavaBeanIntrospector

        public static final String BEAN_useJavaBeanIntrospector
        Use Java Introspector for determining bean properties (Boolean, default=false).

        Using the built-in Java bean introspector will not pick up fields or non-standard getters/setters. Most @Bean annotations will be ignored.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_useInterfaceProxies

        public static final String BEAN_useInterfaceProxies
        Use interface proxies (Boolean, default=true).

        If true, then interfaces will be instantiated as proxy classes through the use of an InvocationHandler if there is no other way of instantiating them.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_ignoreUnknownBeanProperties

        public static final String BEAN_ignoreUnknownBeanProperties
        Ignore unknown properties (Boolean, default=false).

        If true, trying to set a value on a non-existent bean property will silently be ignored. Otherwise, a RuntimeException is thrown.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_ignoreUnknownNullBeanProperties

        public static final String BEAN_ignoreUnknownNullBeanProperties
        Ignore unknown properties with null values (Boolean, default=true).

        If true, trying to set a null value on a non-existent bean property will silently be ignored. Otherwise, a RuntimeException is thrown.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_ignorePropertiesWithoutSetters

        public static final String BEAN_ignorePropertiesWithoutSetters
        Ignore properties without setters (Boolean, default=true).

        If true, trying to set a value on a bean property without a setter will silently be ignored. Otherwise, a RuntimeException is thrown.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_ignoreInvocationExceptionsOnGetters

        public static final String BEAN_ignoreInvocationExceptionsOnGetters
        Ignore invocation errors on getters (Boolean, default=false).

        If true, errors thrown when calling bean getter methods will silently be ignored. Otherwise, a BeanRuntimeException is thrown.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_ignoreInvocationExceptionsOnSetters

        public static final String BEAN_ignoreInvocationExceptionsOnSetters
        Ignore invocation errors on setters (Boolean, default=false).

        If true, errors thrown when calling bean setter methods will silently be ignored. Otherwise, a BeanRuntimeException is thrown.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_sortProperties

        public static final String BEAN_sortProperties
        Sort bean properties in alphabetical order (Boolean, default=false).

        When true, all bean properties will be serialized and access in alphabetical order. Otherwise, the natural order of the bean properties is used which is dependent on the JVM vendor. On IBM JVMs, the bean properties are ordered based on their ordering in the Java file. On Oracle JVMs, the bean properties are not ordered (which follows the offical JVM specs).

        This property is disabled by default so that IBM JVM users don't have to use @Bean annotations to force bean properties to be in a particular order and can just alter the order of the fields/methods in the Java file.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_notBeanPackages

        public static final String BEAN_notBeanPackages
        List of packages whose classes should not be considered beans (Set<String>).

        When specified, the current list of ignore packages are appended to. The default list of ignore packages are as follows:

        • java.lang
        • java.lang.annotation
        • java.lang.ref
        • java.lang.reflect
        • java.io
        • java.net
        • java.nio.*
        • java.util.*

        Any classes within these packages will be serialized to strings using Object.toString().

        Note that you can specify prefix patterns to include all subpackages.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_notBeanPackages_add

        public static final String BEAN_notBeanPackages_add
        Add to the list of packages whose classes should not be considered beans.
        See Also:

        public static final String BEAN_notBeanPackages_remove
        Remove from the list of packages whose classes should not be considered beans.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_notBeanClasses

        public static final String BEAN_notBeanClasses
        An explicit list of Java classes to be excluded from consideration as being beans (Set<Class>).

        Not-bean classes are typically converted to Strings during serialization even if they appear to be bean-like.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_transforms

        public static final String BEAN_transforms
        List of transform classes on the bean context (List<Class>).

        There are two category of classes that can be passed in through this method:

        • Subclasses of PojoTransform and BeanTransform.
        • Any other class.

        When Transform classes are specified, they identify objects that need to be transformed into some other type during serialization (and optionally the reverse during parsing).

        When non-Transform classes are specified, they are wrapped inside BeanTransforms. For example, if you have an interface IFoo and a subclass Foo, and you only want properties defined on IFoo to be visible as bean properties for Foo objects, you can simply pass in IFoo.class to this method.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_transforms_add

        public static final String BEAN_transforms_add
        Add to the list of transform classes.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_transforms_remove

        public static final String BEAN_transforms_remove
        Remove from the list of transform classes.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_implClasses

        public static final String BEAN_implClasses
        Specifies implementation classes for an interface or abstract class (Map<Class,Class>).

        For interfaces and abstract classes this method can be used to specify an implementation class for the interface/abstract class so that instances of the implementation class are used when instantiated (e.g. during a parse).

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • BEAN_implClasses_put

      • dumpCacheStats

        protected static void dumpCacheStats()

      • forBean

        public <T> BeanMap<T> forBean(T o)
        Wraps an object inside a BeanMap object (i.e. a modifiable Map).

        If object is not a true bean, then throws a BeanRuntimeException with an explanation of why it's not a bean.

        Example:

        // Construct a bean map around a bean instance BeanMap<Person> bm = BeanContext.DEFAULT.forBean(new Person());

        Type Parameters:
        T - The class of the object being wrapped.
        Parameters:
        o - The object to wrap in a map interface. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The wrapped object.

      • isBean

        public boolean isBean(Object o)
        Determines whether the specified object matches the requirements on this context of being a bean.
        Parameters:
        o - The object being tested.
        Returns:
        true if the specified object is considered a bean.

      • isBean

        public boolean isBean(Class<?> c)
        Determines whether the specified class matches the requirements on this context of being a bean.
        Parameters:
        c - The class being tested.
        Returns:
        true if the specified class is considered a bean.

      • forBean

        public <T> BeanMap<T> forBean(T o,
                              Class<? super T> c)
                       throws BeanRuntimeException
        Wraps an object inside a BeanMap object (i.e.: a modifiable Map) defined as a bean for one of its class, a super class, or an implemented interface.

        If object is not a true bean, throws a BeanRuntimeException with an explanation of why it's not a bean.

        Example:

        // Construct a bean map for new bean using only properties defined in a superclass BeanMap<MySubBean> bm = BeanContext.DEFAULT.forBean(new MySubBean(), MySuperBean.class); // Construct a bean map for new bean using only properties defined in an interface BeanMap<MySubBean> bm = BeanContext.DEFAULT.forBean(new MySubBean(), MySuperInterface.class);

        Type Parameters:
        T - The class of the object being wrapped.
        Parameters:
        o - The object to wrap in a bean interface. Must not be null.
        c - The superclass to narrow the bean properties to. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The bean representation, or null if the object is not a true bean.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If either parameter is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified object is not an an instance of the specified class.
        BeanRuntimeException - If specified object is not a bean according to the bean rules specified in this context class.

      • newBeanMap

        public <T> BeanMap<T> newBeanMap(Class<T> c)
        Creates a new BeanMap object (i.e. a modifiable Map) of the given class with uninitialized property values.

        If object is not a true bean, then throws a BeanRuntimeException with an explanation of why it's not a bean.

        Example:

        // Construct a new bean map wrapped around a new Person object BeanMap<Person> bm = BeanContext.DEFAULT.newBeanMap(Person.class);

        Type Parameters:
        T - The class of the object being wrapped.
        Parameters:
        c - The name of the class to create a new instance of.
        Returns:
        A new instance of the class.

      • newBeanMap

        public <T> BeanMap<T> newBeanMap(Object outer,
                                 Class<T> c)
        Same as newBeanMap(Class), except used for instantiating inner member classes that must be instantiated within another class instance.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The class of the object being wrapped.
        Parameters:
        c - The name of the class to create a new instance of.
        outer - If class is a member class, this is the instance of the containing class. Should be null if not a member class.
        Returns:
        A new instance of the class.

      • newBean

        public <T> T newBean(Class<T> c)
              throws BeanRuntimeException
        Creates a new empty bean of the specified type, except used for instantiating inner member classes that must be instantiated within another class instance.
        Example:

        // Construct a new instance of the specified bean class Person p = BeanContext.DEFAULT.newBean(Person.class);

        Type Parameters:
        T - The class type of the bean being created.
        Parameters:
        c - The class type of the bean being created.
        Returns:
        A new bean object.
        Throws:
        BeanRuntimeException - If the specified class is not a valid bean.

      • newBean

        public <T> T newBean(Object outer,
                     Class<T> c)
              throws BeanRuntimeException
        Same as newBean(Class), except used for instantiating inner member classes that must be instantiated within another class instance.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The class type of the bean being created.
        Parameters:
        c - The class type of the bean being created.
        outer - If class is a member class, this is the instance of the containing class. Should be null if not a member class.
        Returns:
        A new bean object.
        Throws:
        BeanRuntimeException - If the specified class is not a valid bean.

      • getBeanMeta

        public <T> BeanMeta<T> getBeanMeta(Class<T> c)
        Returns the BeanMeta class for the specified class.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The class type to get the meta-data on.
        Parameters:
        c - The class to get the meta-data on.
        Returns:
        The BeanMeta for the specified class, or null if the class is not a bean per the settings on this context.

      • normalizeClassMeta

        public <T> ClassMeta<T> normalizeClassMeta(ClassMeta<T> cm)
        Returns the class type bound to this bean context if the specified class type is from another bean context.

        For example, this method allows you to pass in an object from BeanContext.DEFAULT.getMapClassMeta(...) to any of the ReaderParser.parse(Reader, ClassMeta, ParserContext) methods, and the parsers will use this method to replace the class type with the one registered with the parser. This ensures that registered transforms are applied correctly.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The class type.
        Parameters:
        cm - The class type.
        Returns:
        The class type bound by this bean context.

      • getClassMeta

        public <T> ClassMeta<T> getClassMeta(Class<T> c)
        Construct a ClassMeta wrapper around a Class object.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The class type being wrapped.
        Parameters:
        c - The class being wrapped. of type Class or ClassMeta.
        Returns:
        If the class is not an array, returns a cached ClassMeta object. Otherwise, returns a new ClassMeta object every time.

      • getMapClassMeta

        public <K,V,T extends Map<K,V>> ClassMeta<T> getMapClassMeta(Class<T> c,
                                                             ClassMeta<K> keyType,
                                                             ClassMeta<V> valueType)
        Construct a ClassMeta wrapper around a Map object.
        Type Parameters:
        K - The map key class type.
        V - The map value class type.
        T - The map class type.
        Parameters:
        c - The map class type.
        keyType - The map key class type.
        valueType - The map value class type.
        Returns:
        If the key and value types are OBJECT, returns a cached ClassMeta object.
        Otherwise, returns a new ClassMeta object every time.

      • getMapClassMeta

      • getClassMeta

        public ClassMeta getClassMeta(Type o)
        Constructs a ClassMeta object given the specified object and parameters.
        Parameters:
        o - The parent class type. Can be any of the following types:
        • ClassMeta object, which just returns the same object.
        • Class object (e.g. String.class).
        • Type object (e.g. ParameterizedType or GenericArrayType.
        • Anything else is interpreted as getClassMeta(o.getClass(), parameters);
        Returns:
        A ClassMeta object, or null if the object is null.

      • getClassMetas

        public ClassMeta<?>[] getClassMetas(Class<?>[] classes)
        Given an array of Class objects, returns an array of corresponding ClassMeta objects. Constructs a new array on each call.
        Parameters:
        classes - The array of classes to get class metas for.
        Returns:
        An array of ClassMeta objects corresponding to the classes. Never null.

      • getClassMetaForObject

        public <T> ClassMeta<T> getClassMetaForObject(T o)
        Shortcut for calling getClassMeta(o.getClass()).
        Type Parameters:
        T - The class of the object being passed in.
        Parameters:
        o - The class to find the class type for.
        Returns:
        The ClassMeta object, or null if o is null.

      • getClassMeta

        protected <T> ClassMeta<T> getClassMeta(BeanProperty p,
                                        Type t,
                                        Map<Class<?>,Class<?>[]> typeVarImpls)
        Used for determining the class type on a method or field where a @BeanProperty annotation may be present.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The class type we're wrapping.
        Parameters:
        p - The property annotation on the type if there is one.
        t - The type.
        typeVarImpls - Contains known resolved type parameters on the specified class so that we can result ParameterizedTypes and TypeVariables.
        Can be null if the information is not known.
        Returns:
        The new ClassMeta object wrapped around the Type object.

      • getClassMetaFromString

        public ClassMeta<?> getClassMetaFromString(String s)
        Converts class name strings to ClassMeta objects.
        Example:
        • "java.lang.String"
        • "com.ibm.sample.MyBean[]"
        • "java.util.HashMap"
        • "[Ljava.lang.String;" (i.e. the value of String[].class.getName())
        Parameters:
        s - The class name.
        Returns:
        The ClassMeta corresponding to the class name string.

        protected <T> PojoTransform findPojoTransform(Class<T> c)
        Returns the PojoTransform associated with the specified class, or null if there is no pojo transform associated with the class.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The class associated with the transform.
        Parameters:
        c - The class associated with the transform.
        Returns:
        The transform associated with the class, or null if there is no association.

      • hasChildPojoTransforms

        protected boolean hasChildPojoTransforms(Class<?> c)
        Checks whether a class has a PojoTransform associated with it in this bean context.
        Parameters:
        c - The class to check.
        Returns:
        true if the specified class or one of its subclasses has a PojoTransform associated with it.

      • convertToType

        public <T> T convertToType(Object value,
                           Class<T> type)
                    throws InvalidDataConversionException
        Converts the specified value to the specified class type.

        See convertToType(Object, ClassMeta) for the list of valid conversions.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The class type to convert the value to.
        Parameters:
        value - The value to convert.
        type - The class type to convert the value to.
        Returns:
        The converted value.
        Throws:
        InvalidDataConversionException - If the specified value cannot be converted to the specified type.

      • convertToType

        public <T> T convertToType(Object outer,
                           Object value,
                           Class<T> type)
                    throws InvalidDataConversionException
        Same as convertToType(Object, Class), except used for instantiating inner member classes that must be instantiated within another class instance.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The class type to convert the value to.
        Parameters:
        outer - If class is a member class, this is the instance of the containing class. Should be null if not a member class.
        value - The value to convert.
        type - The class type to convert the value to.
        Returns:
        The converted value.
        Throws:
        InvalidDataConversionException - If the specified value cannot be converted to the specified type.

      • object

        public ClassMeta<Object> object()
        Returns a reusable ClassMeta representation for the class Object.

        This ClassMeta is often used to represent "any object type" when an object type is not known.

        This method is identical to calling getClassMeta(Object.class) but uses a cached copy to avoid a hashmap lookup.

        Returns:
        The ClassMeta object associated with the Object class.

      • string

        public ClassMeta<String> string()
        Returns a reusable ClassMeta representation for the class String.

        This ClassMeta is often used to represent key types in maps.

        This method is identical to calling getClassMeta(String.class) but uses a cached copy to avoid a hashmap lookup.

        Returns:
        The ClassMeta object associated with the String class.

      • _class

        public ClassMeta<Class> _class()
        Returns a reusable ClassMeta representation for the class Class.

        This ClassMeta is often used to represent key types in maps.

        This method is identical to calling getClassMeta(Class.class) but uses a cached copy to avoid a hashmap lookup.

        Returns:
        The ClassMeta object associated with the String class.

      • convertToType

        public <T> T convertToType(Object value,
                           ClassMeta<T> type)
                    throws InvalidDataConversionException
        Casts the specified value into the specified type.

        If the value isn't an instance of the specified type, then converts the value if possible.

        The following conversions are valid:

        Convert to typeValid input value typesNotes
        A class that is the normal type of a registered PojoTransform. A value whose class matches the transformed type of that registered PojoTransform.  
        A class that is the transformed type of a registered PojoTransform. A value whose class matches the normal type of that registered PojoTransform.  
        Number (e.g. Integer, Short, Float,...)
        Number.TYPE (e.g. Integer.TYPE, Short.TYPE, Float.TYPE,...)         		Number, String, null For primitive TYPES, null returns the JVM default value for that type.
        Map (e.g. Map, HashMap, TreeMap, ObjectMap) Map If Map is not constructible, a ObjectMap is created.
        Collection (e.g. List, LinkedList, HashSet, ObjectList) Collection<Object>
        Object[]         		If Collection is not constructible, a ObjectList is created.
        X[] (array of any type X)
        		 List<X>
        		  
        X[][] (multi-dimensional arrays)
        		 List<List<X>>
        List<X[]>
        List[]<X>
        		  
        Enum
        		 String
        		  
        Bean
        		 Map
        		  
        String
        		 Anything
        		 Arrays are converted to JSON arrays
        Anything with one of the following methods:
        public static T fromString(String)
        public static T valueOf(String)
        public T(String)
        		 String
        Type Parameters:
        T - The class type to convert the value to.
        Parameters:
        value - The value to be converted.
        type - The target object type.
        Returns:
        The converted type.
        Throws:
        InvalidDataConversionException - If the specified value cannot be converted to the specified type.

      • convertToType

        public <T> T convertToType(Object outer,
                           Object value,
                           ClassMeta<T> type)
                    throws InvalidDataConversionException
        Same as convertToType(Object, ClassMeta), except used for instantiating inner member classes that must be instantiated within another class instance.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The class type to convert the value to.
        Parameters:
        outer - If class is a member class, this is the instance of the containing class. Should be null if not a member class.
        value - The value to convert.
        type - The class type to convert the value to.
        Returns:
        The converted value.
        Throws:
        InvalidDataConversionException - If the specified value cannot be converted to the specified type.

      • toArray

        public Object toArray(ClassMeta<?> type,
                      Collection<?> list)
        Converts the contents of the specified list into an array.

        Works on both object and primitive arrays.

        In the case of multi-dimensional arrays, the incoming list must contain elements of type n-1 dimension. i.e. if type is int[][] then list must have entries of type int[].

        Parameters:
        type - The type to convert to. Must be an array type.
        list - The contents to populate the array with.
        Returns:
        A new object or primitive array.

        Returns:
        The classloader associated with this bean context.
